numbered_ace_sentences: 1. The graph has several categories.
2. In every category, young women reach out to their parents more often than young men.
3. For both genders, texting is the most common form of communication with parents.
4. Texting is convenient.
5. Texting is mobile.
6. A phone call is less convenient than texting.
7. Traveling home to see parents is less convenient than texting.
8. Visiting parents in person is the least common way to reach out to parents.
9. Many people who are 18-22 are away from home at college.
10. If a person is away from home at college then the person cannot visit home often.
11. Many people who are 22-34 work where they can find a job.
12. Often a job is not in a person's hometown.
13. If a job is not in a person's hometown then the person cannot visit parents often.
14. Women have a higher overall percentage of reaching out than men.
15. I wonder why women have a higher overall percentage of reaching out than men.
16. I wonder whether the proximity of a college to a hometown plays a role in communication.
17. If a person visits parents a few times a week then the person may text parents less often.
18. If a person visits parents a few times a week then the person may call parents less often.
19. The study includes kids in college.
20. The study includes people who work.
21. I want to know whether kids in college communicate more than people who work.
22. I am a male.
23. I am in college.
24. I call my parents every day.
25. In the age bracket, most males do not call their parents every day.
26. I am in the minority of males in the age bracket.
27. Keeping in touch with parents helps to keep a strong relationship with parents.
28. Being in college is different from early life.
29. In early life, we saw our parents every day.
30. The headline is: Keeping in Touch, Who Does It Best?
